content.description:
Steep entabulature sloper wrangling. There is a sweet roof at the top of the climb where the rock changes from entabulature to a big orange/tan face with a tiny seam running through it. The bolt is right where you need it and clippable before entering the crux.

The crux revolves around managing to get your paws into the couple spots where the seam opens up enough for marginal jamming. Crux may seem very hard for the grade at first but dumbs down with beta. Similar in difficulty to Aboriginal Designs.
content.location:
This climb currently does not have a proper start. It should start in the dirty, currently unprotectable corner to the left of the start of Stones in the Pathway, but there aren't any bolts. If you have some finger sized cams / nuts, I guess you could place them in the ditry crack You'll know the base of this route by the ~leg sized tree that was cut down a couple feet right of t's base, freshly as of 2020.

Best bet now is to climb the start of Stones in the Pathway and clip the two bolts protecting that corner with a couple alpine draws and deal with a little rope drag. Or you could do what I did and just solo this ~5.7 corner, watching out for the bits of moss/lichen that make the rock slippery in spots.

content.description: Long sustained route.  Positive holds, the crux is at the roof.
content.protection: 10 bolts, short chain on the edge of the roof, use longs draws to avoid rope drap from the roof
content.location: First climb to the left of the pictograph.

climbs.name: Abandonings
climbs.fa: FA Andy Fitz  FFA Dave Moroles October 1995

content.description: Begin on the shared start with Middle Passage (a 5.5 unprotected corner unless you bring trad gear), clip the intermediate anchor and then head up and right into steep terrain with sloping holds.  Continue up over a bulge and into a cool corner feature.  After pulling through the corner, move around a prow to the left on good holds and then pull a few moves past the last bolt on the vertical upper wall.
content.protection: The book says 9 bolts, but it seemed like there were a few more than that.
content.location: Shared start with Middle Passage, then up and right.

content.description: Start in the hand crack just right of the pictographs. Climb past 2 ledges and into the overhanging crux. Use runners as needed. A 60M ROPE COULD WORK, BUT TIE A KNOT. Fixed clips on chain anchors.
content.location: Tan hanger at the top of the hand crack, left of mass wasting, and right of the pictographs.

content.description:
Start in a loose but easy corner, then launch up steepish terrain with the usual basalt entablature blocky sloper jugs.

This route is listed as 7. Project in the Tieton guidebook. Clearly it's been finished and is climbed fairly often, so I'm mostly posting this here to see if anyone who knows who did it and what they named it wants to volunteer any information. Obviously I don't know the official rating but it seemed easier than Relics.

Slopers, edges, and pinches carry you through steep rock over a couple minor roofs. There is a rattly finger / ringlock sized crack at the top you might want to bring a couple cams for in the .4-.75 range to avoid a ~15 ft runout. On my red point I forgot the cams and it wasn't a big deal, the crack is about 10a.

The crux is a cool sequence starting with traversing under a small roof using some underclings and the slopy lip of the roof and then doing some really, super balancey climbing through a few more bolts til you arrive at another, easier roof beneath the final crack. Great climb.
content.location: Look for the corner/dihedral feature on the lower band of mossy rock that has two bolts on the left side of it. That's the start of the route. Getting into that corner is a little weird no matter which side you come from, consider stick clipping the first bolt.

content.description: Scramble up to a small ledge and climb the blocky face to another ledge just left of the obvious roof.  Make a short traverse right, then climb the corner up to the steep and exposed finish.
content.protection: The FA used only the bolts; many climbers will want to protect the long obvious run out with a .75 Camalot, and maybe a red C3 after the bolt marking the start of the crux getting into the corner
content.location: The longest, obvious line on the left hand side on the middle wall.  Just left of Casting Stones.  Just right of the short 3 bolt climb Haiku.

content.description: Well protected, positive holds.  Crux starts as the rock becomes steeper.  Finish at anchor set below roof.
content.location: Third route to the left of the pictograph.

content.description:
Very fun climbing, similar holds and movement to all the other neighboring routes. This one is distinguished by a crux moving through a bulge in the middle of the route followed by tricky, balancey climbing through a corner pulling onto the orange/tan upper face. A knee bar as you emerge from the corner can be helpful.

Very cool to climb on two distinct rock types on this route with the finish being straight up face climbing on a crack/flake feature and the lower part being tricky 3d and body positioning intensive climbing on wavy slopers.
content.location:
This climb shares a start with Abandonings. Look for the clean finger crack set back in a right facing corner/dihedral. Takes finger sized gear, or you can free solo this ~25 ft section of 5.7ish corner crack climbing. After climbing this corner, you will come to an anchor featuring two huge, tan hangers. This climb takes the line of bolts to the left of that anchor.

Book says to finish on Stones in the Pathway's anchors, but it makes more sense to finish right, on the anchor for Abandonings. Optional ~.5 cam for this finish.

climbs.name: Mass Wasting
climbs.fa: FA: Andy Fitz, Ed Mosshart, 1997  FFA: Jim Yoder, March 2002

content.description:
Climb 5.8 in a corner up to a two-bolt anchor, then continue up moderate terrain with some moves past a roof at ~5.10d or so to a ledge where the route cuts right and through the crux roof.  Clip a long draw on the bolt below the roof and set off on the adventure.

Watch out for a hollow-sounding block that you end up hugging with both hands.  Good holds bring you to the next bolt, but things get quite a bit more difficult for the next two clips.  Sloping holds below the roof get you to some critical, tough-to-find crimpers just above the roof.

If you can make it to a good jug at the next clip, you just need to keep it together on the final headwall with small edges to the chains.  Great route.
content.protection: 12 bolts, including clipping an anchor part of the way up
content.location: Far right end of The Cave, right of the pictograph

content.description: Short but good.  3 bolts.  Climb the seam through the left hand side of the roof.
content.location: Currently, the farthest left hand route on the middle wall.  Walk down hill a bit, left of Skynet
